Message.Title: **** FBI Issues Warning Regarding Android Malware ****
Message.Msg: **** FBI Issues Warning to Smartphone Users Regarding Android Malware **** Monday, October 15, 2012, 02:44 pm By Slash Lane "The FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center has issued a Warning alerting users about Malware that targets the Android mobile operating system. It noted there are various forms of Malware out in the wild that Attack Android devices. Two forms of malware cited by the FBI IC3 are Loozfon, which Steals Information from Users, and FinFisher, which can give Nefarious Hackers control over a user's device. Loozfon can lure in Victims by promising users a work-at-home opportunity in exchange for sending out an e-mail. Visiting a link in the e-mail will push Loozfon to the user's device, Allowing the Malware to Steal contact details from the device's address book. The FinFisher spyware highlighted by the IC3 allows for a mobile device to be remotely controlled and monitored from anywhere. FinFisher is installed by simply visiting a Web link or opening a text message that Disguises itself as a system update. The Presence of Malware on Android Has Been Known For Some Time, while Apple's tightly controlled iOS platform is far less susceptible to malware." Ignore the FBI Warning at your own peril, boys. Android = Nefarious Hackers which Steal your information = Bad. Apple = Tightly controlled, far less susceptible iOS platform = iGood. Isn't that one of those oxymorons? An Android smartphone user?

Message.Title: Reuters: Amazon in talks to buy TI mobile chip arm
Message.Msg: Reuters: Amazon in talks to buy TI mobile chip arm Oh my! My my my. Poor already struggling nvidia.

Topic.Title: Reuters: Amazon in talks to buy TI mobile chip arm

Message.Msg: "Owning its own chip business could save Amazon money if it plans to sell larger quantities of mobile devices. It could also help Amazon design better products. "Look at Bezos and what he's trying to build. I think he would consider himself of the Steve Jobs ilk," said Williams Financial analyst Cody Acree. "If it works for Apple then why wouldn't it work as well or better for Amazon?" Some analysts questioned whether it would make sense for Amazon to get into the semiconductor business when many smaller and independent smartphone [tegra] chip makers are struggling."

Topic.Title: Reuters: Amazon in talks to buy TI mobile chip arm

Message.Title: Microsoft Surface RT price official: Starting at $499
Message.Msg: Update: Microsoft has officially announced the Surface RTâs price (no change from whatâs below). â Seemingly accidentally, Microsoft has unveiled the pricing for its Surface Windows RT tablets on its online store this morning: The base unit with 32 gigabytes of storage will go for $499, making it the ideal iPad killer, while the 32GB model with a Touch Cover Keyboard will cost $599. At the high-end, Microsoft will offer a 64GB Surface with a Touch Cover for $699. All of the models show October 26th as a shipping date. Microsoft also lists the Touch Cover separately for for $119, which features a flat touch keyboard, while the version with a more traditional keyboard costs $129. Pricing was one of the many key details Microsoft left out when it unveiled the Surface tablets in June, and Iâm sure the company wanted to make a bigger deal of having an iPad competitive $499 price. Youâll be able to pre-order a Surface at Microsoftâs site starting at 9 am Pacific today, or you can pick one up at a Microsoft store on October 26. The Surface RT pricing is surprisingly level-headed for Microsoft, though a part of me wishes the company went the extra mile to price it below $499. Given that Microsoft is starving for tablet market share, it would have made sense to aim for a $399 or $450. Then again, given just how slick the Surface looks, Microsoft may already be losing money on the Surface RTâs $499 price. Weâre still awaiting pricing on the slightly larger Microsoft Surface running Windows 8 Pro, which will be able to run existing Windows programs and sport more powerful hardware (at the cost of being heavier). Since that Surface is basically a full-fledged PC, itâs expected to sell for $800 to $1,000. Windows RT devices, including the Surface, will only be able to run new Windows 8 apps from Microsoftâs app store.

Topic.Title: Long article in Chicago Tribune: As PC era fades, good times may be over at Intel

Message.Msg: Windows 8 and the awesome Haswell will kickstart PC sales next year. Intel CloverTrail Windows 8 enterprise tablets should also sell well. The bottom line is profits not gross margins and those will continue on an upward trend as Atom volume increases again from tablets and phones while Haswell and Server sales keep the gross margins up. Intel's gross margins increased when it stopped trying to kill AMD in price and marketshare wars but the extra marketshare it had then more than made the profits up. There is plenty of slack in Intel's pricing to take any ARM threat in its stride. In 2014 there will be 5W quad-issue eight-port dual-core with hyper-threading 14nm Broadwells facing the highest performance ARM quad-cores in the top tablets. It will be a bloody performance slaughter of the 20nm S4/A15 chips.

Message.Title: Intel profit slips, sales fall
Message.Msg: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Intel Corp. INTC -2.37% on Tuesday reported a third-quarter profit of $2.97 billion, or 58 cents a share, compared with a profit of $3.47 billion, or 65 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Revenue was $13.46 billion, down from $14.23 billion. Adjusted profit was 60 cents a share. Analysts were expecting Intel to report a profit of 50 cents a share, on revenue of $13.2 billion, according to a consensus survey by FactSet. For the current quarter, Intel expects revenue of $13.6 billion, plus or minus $500 million. Analysts were expecting sales of $13.7 billion, according to FactSet. Intel shares were down 1% in after-hours trading.

Topic.Title: maybe time for intel to by nvda?

Message.Msg: With 80% of their GPU chips ending-up in good 'ole PC's and laptops, nvidia IS a PC parts maker. And that's what they'll die doing, boys. Making PC graphics parts that attach to Intel and AMD processors. Sure, nvidia can put on a costume and Pretend to be in mobile with their $400 million-a-year Loss making Tegra. But it's just a bad costume. And an expensive one too. Everybody knows they're still a dying PC parts maker. It's far better for Intel to invest in improving their own integrated graphics, than waste money on a washed-up graphics attachment house.

Topic.Title: LIKE AN APPLE: MICROSOFT WILL DESIGN THEIR OWN ARM CHIP INTEL DOOMED

Message.Msg: Where do you see that specific figure? I do believe that Tegra is losing money currently. Jen-Hsun Huang has hinted on CC's in the past that CPB needs to do ~$1B annually to be profitable -- which I think implies they need to sell ~40M SoCs annually from the Tegra line. Q3 should show a lot more progress getting there than Q2 did, considering that Q2 barely captured the limited launch of the Nexus 7.
